The specific comment I linked to was about managing a list of default system paths to certs (which BTW doesn't help on Windows, or OS X, since the OS X path in the thread no longer is shipped with OS X):

``` python
cert_paths = [
    # Debian, Ubuntu, Arch, SuSE
    # NetBSD (security/mozilla-rootcerts)
    "/etc/ssl/certs/",
    # Debian, Ubuntu, Arch: maintained by update-ca-certificates
    "/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt",
    # Red Hat 5+, Fedora, Centos
    "/etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt",
    # Red Hat 4
    "/usr/share/ssl/certs/ca-bundle.crt",
    # FreeBSD (security/ca-root-nss package)
    "/usr/local/share/certs/ca-root-nss.crt",
    # FreeBSD (deprecated security/ca-root package, removed 2008)
    "/usr/local/share/certs/ca-root.crt",
    # FreeBSD (optional symlink)
    # OpenBSD
    "/etc/ssl/cert.pem",
    # Mac OS X
    "/System/Library/OpenSSL/certs/cert.pem",
    ]
```

The reason I mentioned `certifi` is because that group of people gave up on managing system paths and just ships a `certs` file in their source code. This is the same thing being suggested here. So either shipping it with `libgrpc` core or ship it with the language specific libraries is the equivalent here. (I'm certainly out of my depth in discussing what is secure or correct, I was just trying to explain the things I've seen.)
Yes, nodejs did that. But nodejs also ships with the C core bundled instead of linking against it, so I have no expectation that our users would have the certificates installed in `/usr/share/grpc/`.

That is another little hitch - we require the core package to already be installed. Seeing as how the core determines the expected paths (or, seemingly, not), shouldn't it then be the core package that distributes the required list?

In that case yes, the roots should come for the installed core package and everything should be working seamlessly thanks to the magic that @nicolasnoble put in the path computation of the default roots file path.

Hmm, so now that we're going to be distributing the core with the Python installation, the certs should somehow be distributed with the installation?

There'd be the (minor, easily worked around) hitch that by design Python packages are not able to install to arbitrary locations. This brings a question: is it a problem thus that the users would never see the certs on their computers in any standard location?

FWIW I recently discovered the `httplib2` also [distributes its own certs](https://github.com/jcgregorio/httplib2/blob/cf631a73e2f3f43897b65206127ced82382d35f5/python2/httplib2/cacerts.txt) and allows the user to [override](https://github.com/jcgregorio/httplib2/blob/cf631a73e2f3f43897b65206127ced82382d35f5/python2/httplib2/__init__.py#L187-L195) if they so choose.

3 proposals to move forward in the new core embedded world in order of my
preference:
1. See if there's a Python library that can dig out the system certs for us
(maybe we get lucky)
2. Bundle the certs as data with the extension
3. Bundle the certs as code with the extension

All would need a hook for users to override the defaults, and that hook to
be very clearly documented.

We should probably have a well known HTTPS address for our users to fetch
them also. I could even imagine providing an API to fetch whatever we think
is latest.

2. Convert them to PEM using
   https://github.com/agl/extract-nss-root-certs.
